content:
0, 2014
Early Access Review
								Below you'll find both a video and written impression of the game.


YouTube™ Video:  

			Views: 0		



Interstellar Marines may come off as a generic tactical shooter upon first impressions, but once you start playing, you'll see that this game has a few interesting mechanics that helps separate this game from the plethora of other tactical FPSs on the market. The game features a very interesting, and realistic lighting system, where some times the map will put players into total darkness. This will force players to start using their flashlight which will of course give them away to enemy fire. Certainly an interesting take on a risk-reward system for a tactical FPS. The game also features mid-match dynamic level alterations. The game map will change, closing and opening new choke points and paths, mid match, in real time. This has a dynamic effect on the game field. Lastly the game features a ridiculous amounts of capture points in it's game mode. This came off as a negative, almost as a design flaw at first, but the more I played I saw what the designer had in mind. This tactical shooter encourages spiting up and covering ground, rather than the usual, 7 man in a choke point cluster F*** that the usual tactical shooter tend to lean towards.The game's audio, and visual is impressive, and it's attention to detail as well as it's lighting is equally so.The game is not with out it's faults though. In it's current stage of early access, there is no single player campaign, minimal tutorial, only one game mode, and only the default rifles hurt this game's variety. The game also has some net code issues as it has noticeable and undeniable bullet lag. Interstellar Marines also face the hurdle of developing a robust and active community, in the face of hundreds if not thousands of other tactical shooters, fighting for the same audience. Currently the game's community is active, but relatively small. Only 1-3 servers will any sort of population at any given time, or even less.But overall, Interstellar Marines is a very enjoyable game that has a pile of potential! I think the game should change it's name as it's incredibly generic, and also promote it's unique light and dark play more to help interest more people.Pros:- Unique Light / Dark mechanic- Unique mid-game battlefield transformation mechanic- Impressive visuals, especially the lighting- Very enjoyable and playable, even as an early accessCons:- Needs more variety- Net code needs a lot of working out- Needs to build a larger community

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
y 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								Once again, I haeve returned to the realm of Gaben to pick up a game. "Oh, joy!" I thought to myself. "I wonder what glorious new things Steam has to offer!"And here it is.Intertellar Marines is an early access first-person shooter based off games such as System Shcock 2 (a good sign) and Counter Strike (a better sign!). However, this is an early access game. Like, really early. Really really really early. How early, you ask? It's in Beta 0.8.5., I think. So yeah, pretty freaking early. It's mostly just a core idea and concept art right now, but this game has potential. Lots of potential.Most indie games have reletively low-res graphics. Not so with this game, which has graphics that could hold their own against a modern AAA game. There's not many mechanics so far. You can lift up your helmet (to give you slightly better visibility and provide a shield from rain) and use your flashlight and laser, both of which are like great, shining beacons of "SH00T H3R3!!1!!1!!" There's also only one gun, an SMG that, quite frankly, sways too much. One would think an accomplished 22nd century space marine could keep an SMG a little steadier, but one would be wrong. Team killing is always enabled, causing some, uh, "misunderstandings" (sorry to all my teammates I killed. You look kind of like the enemy). On occasion, a teammate will walk in front of you in a firefight and you'll accidently blow his damn fool head off. I can imagine it now... "But Sir, he walked into my bullets! It's not my fault!"The weather system is superb. Sometimes it'll rain, sometimes it'll snow, other times it'll be dark as ♥♥♥♥ and you won't be able to see, so you will naturally turn on your flashlight and promptly get a welcome committee from your enemie's bullets. The game lets you be as stealthy as you want, escecially in dark areas. Watch out when it gets dark, the ninjas are everywhere...So, all in all, for a hyper-early access game, Interstellar Marines has loads of potential. So guys? Make Interstellar Marines badass. You have my confidence.

content:
28, 2014
Early Access Review
								The game has a short learning curve, and is very frustrating at first when you you're first learning to see the enemy. But once you get that down, the gameplay is pretty tight. I get frustrated with how vague the mechanics are though; you can be spraying your opponent down in CQC and nobody will land shots, and it's unclear how the gunplay really works. I just kinda go with the flow and things generally work out though. I can't wait to see VoIP implemented, because this game could be very fun to play competetively with a team. It's tight. But god damn, give me a RIFLE would you? The SMG is the only weapon in the game as of 3.28.14, but they plan on adding more. All in all, not my favorite yet, but I'm loving where it's going and it's not going to go into my Steam Graveyard like so many other titles.

Early Access Review
								Best gaming experience i've had so far. The depth given by the game is amazing. it perfectly takes your mind from your head and puts it inside the games Helmet and HUD and give you the most fantastic game graphics; lighting and atmosphere (musical and visual).Its really a mind twist from all those games up there, with hints and in-game aim assist all delivered by a guy that liked to sing; had money but no voice; became a rap\pop\rasta\turqish serenades\romanian dancing and got a gig on your games music...To sum it up is hard but here it goes:Stuning Concept of Depth trough the active helmet which adds 1 more level above other games that try to imerse you in.Breath Taking game modes and by that i mean your forever in motion objectives.Day and Night simulation is even more breath taking then the last one, being trown in pitch black darkness, with dim coloured light pulsing from the suit; buildings; laser or gun fire and having to guess if the guy in front of you is your teammate or not,Amazing Graphics delivered with a unreal briliance mixed, with amazing ambient (visual or graphical) powered by brilliant innovating minds that created this 3D Surreal First Person Shooter and so on for some time.Worth the triple price i've paid for the Spearhead Edition.

								This looks like it could be an amazing game. I dont understand how one of the first implementations was not Controller support though? It looks to me like the team has spent a lot of time creating different environment modes that turn on in graphical fashions with rotating arches carrying lights which seems besides the point to me. It is cool but I don't understand how it in anyway revolutionary. I read reviews saying that even at an early stage this is a completely playable game but i disagree, At the moment it is just running around empty maps. There are about 9 servers all of which are completely full whenever I try to join. The rest ofthe levels are just empty "Playgrounds". The sandbox mode is interesting and displays the damage system well but in the back ground there is a wierd repeating track of someone with such a thick accent coimplaining about something that the only word you can pick out is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ each time it repeats.I am very much looking forward to playing this game when it is playable. But at the moment I don't understand it. It is early release because you want to recieve feedback but at the moment the only feedback i have is add Controller support. Beyond that I have noting to provide feedback about!

								First of all what you need to know is that as of right now when im writing this review (22-1-2015) the game is still in the Pre Alpha Stage of development and that it is developed by an Indie Studio. Early Access Review
								Here's the conversation me and my friend had after playing a couple of games of IM:Dansrage: whats the point of this I can just play Insurgency lol Arthur Von Winklehammer: Right dude? Dansrage: let's go play play InsurgencyArthur Von Winklehammer: aha alright  Visually this game is quite impressive, excluding the endlessly copy/paste assets and environments, the lighting is nice, the weapon models are good, the rain on your visor is reminiscent of Metroid Prime, but there's just nothing under the hood.There are three game modes in IM, Campaign, Coop and Multiplayer. In campaign and coop you'll play on the exact same maps, with the exact same bots. There are minor variations of gametype that essentially boil down to "kill all the guys" or "press all the buttons while you kill the guys". This isn't bad in itself if the gameplay is engaging, but unfortunately it isn't. Bot AI will either run directly into your bullets or stand still and fire at you. The atmosphere with it's excellent sound design and moody lighting is obviously aiming for creepy, but all that ends up happening is that the four players fan out and clobber clueless bots, there's no tension, no real danger besides a bot spawning on you.  The multiplayer is just Insurgency with fewer guns, less varied maps and worse mechanics. It's a bog-standard twitch shooter with the supposed realistic weapon handling counting for nothing when everyone is hip firing in corridors at point blank range. All of the levels look like they're built from a single tileset as if they've been randomly generated. Everything looks the same.It's pretty much impossible to play with your friends, you can't create servers, the only way to host a private game is to set your preference to "friends only", and then try to join one of the seemingly random servers that pops up while it's still empty, hoping that it's the gametype and map that you want, and that you won't be instantly spawnkilled by somebody who wants this server for themselves. There's also seemingly no way to change map or gametype once you're in the server. This game uses "Early Access" as a blanket excuse for laziness, this game has been in development since May 2005.Think about that for a moment.TEN YEARS! It was originally supposed to release on PC and 7th gen consoles, this current version of the game that you're able to play today was Kickstarted in 2012, and is itself three years old.This is all they have to show for it. This is the game. If you think the core mechanics and gameplay will improve from here you're optimistic, I'll give you that, because three years of work has given us an "Early Access Alpha" with off the shelf shooting mechanics and about as much content as a Kinder Surprise. My bet is they're going to tack on more "campaigns" which basically amount to offline bot matches with text-to-speech voiceovers.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								WARNING: THIS REVIEW REFLECTS MY PERSONAL EXPERIENCE DURING THE ALPHA STAGE OF DEVELOPMENT, UPDATE 12IT IS IN NO WAY A FULL PRODUCT REVIEW AND IT WILL BE UPDATED IN THE FUTURE AS THE GAME EVOLVESUPDATE: CHECK AT THE BOTTOM FOR UPDATE 10, 11 and 12!Interstellar Marines is a tactical shooter which aims to innovate several aspect of co-operative teamplay, and succeeds in doing so.While it's still in a very Alpha stage, (there's only one gun, the assault rifle, and there's only one game mode, king of the hill domination) it already started showing why this shooter brings something new to the table.In this game, your helmet is your UI. You take your helmet off, and you resign seeing tactical info like scoreboard, ammo, health, shield, teammate positions, next rank, and so on. The thing is it also gives you advantages. While using your helmet provides good info like that, it also muffles the sounds surrounding you, which makes it hard to hear if there's someone walking nearby. Also, when fighting in some scenarios with weather like raining or snowing, or while looking straight to the light, your sight will get blurried, either by the raindrops falling on your helmet, or because of the cold, or because of the light refraction. Also, your helmet will get dirty as you go through the map under different effects so it will get blurrier and blurrier. Taking your helmet off and putting it on at the right times gives you tactical advantage.Friendly fire is always on and at 100% damage rate, which is great because that is the way it should be.While the game currently lacks of many standard features like crouching and going prone, it already shows promise.CURRENT STATUS AS OF FEBRUARY 11, 2014PROS- Innovative helmet UI system.- Great settings, from storms to dark caves.- EXCELLENT, and I can't even begin to describe how good they are, SOUNDS. I mean, you feel like you're really there. I dare you stand under the rain in this game and not loving how it sounds when it falls on your suit.- Fair and balanced gameplay (seriously, the most balanced shooter I've seen so far).- Each match has several rounds changing the setting of the map (it can rain, it can become dark, it can be under a bright sunlight, it can snow, and all during a single match, making taking the helmet on and off something necessary).- Optimized engine, no FPS drops so far, while looking beautiful at the same time.- You can play with lag and almost not even notice it.- Shadows and body immersion is really good. You can see your own body looking below, and you can calculate if you're hiding well or not.- Great hitboxes. No refrigerator box here.- The best online community I have ever found around a game. No hate, just good people. Really, I've never had so much fun talking with people inside a game until playing this. I must congratulate every single one of you guys for being so awesome!CONS- No ducking at the time. (ADDED IN UPDATE 10!)- No proning at the time. (ADDED IN UPDATE 10!)- Only one weapon (assault rifle) at the time.- Only one gamemode (king of the hill team deathmatch) at the time.- Few servers (all official alpha servers) at the time. (ADDED MORE SERVERS IN UPDATE 10!)Is it worth its full price at the time? Nnnnn... maybe. I'd say wait before going full price on it.Is it worth purchasing in the IndieGala Bundle with the Beat The Average bonus? Yes. You should buy it that way.Will it be worth its full price in the future (if all goes according to plan)? Yes!Long story short: buy it discounted at the time, or wait a while until it gets better. But it's already showing stuff worth seeing. If you like tactical shooters, you should join their community group in the hub and keep track of its progress.  It may be just what you were looking for.______________________________________UPDATE 10 BROUGHT A LOT OF CHANGES!- Added jump.- Added crouch.- Better HUD.- Added new model for weapon (more hi-res).- Added more maps!- Added more servers.- Added more environments (wind and hard rain).- Added better lighting effects.- Added better reflections.Now it's worth its full price. Go get it!______________________________________UPDATE 11 BROUGHT NEW MAPS!______________________________________UPDATE 12 BROUGHT NEW GAMEPLAY!- Added new gamemode: capture points.- Added new weapon! Assault rifle w/scope.- Rain effects look better.

Early Access Review
								Early Access Summary:Gameplay: 9Music: 10Sound: 9Graphics: 7Community: 7Devs: 9Overall Review of Early Access: 8/10System Requirements: Anything made in the last 5 years, excluding chromebooksFull Early Access Review:One of the best Tactical Shooters on Steam right now. Incredibly immersive, the sound, lighting, and level design is top notch. Content wise, the game is slowly growing, with more multiplayer maps every couple updates, and more singleplayer every couple months.Eventually, the devs have promised (And I don't doubt they will deliver) a full co-op campaign, with RPG elements. Considering the game is already my favorite co-op experience besides Payday 2, I'd say Interstellar Marines could be THE co-op game for the next few years. The Dev's have Twitch broadcasts quite often, and are also very active on the forums. (At their website, not as much on steam)The game is well worth the $15, but I went all out and got Spearhead. I refuse to pre-order or buy early access to almost all games, but this is definitely worth it.Score: 8/10. Wins the Sorrowful Award for Legitness.Buy it now, or if you are hesitant, buy it on sale.Either way, you won't be dissapointed.

content:
er 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								Although the Devs may take their time with game updates.  I'm grateful for the amount of content that has been released within the past few years. This gets me rather  excited for what is to come upon the next few months. Mostly because of the amount of game content that we have now is rather impressive. The game has multiple modes that such as Single player and  Coop campaign missions, Horde style game modes where players must defend off waves of killer robots,  and the standard multiplayer team deathmatch where players must take over control points in order for their team to win. (  think of it like the Conquest mode from the  battlefield games but on a smaller scale.)  And lets not forget that this game has a hunger games-ish gamemode where players are put against each other  in LARGE maps. The main idea is to be the last man( or woman) to  survive the hour long match. The graphics in this game is great to look at.  the lighting and the sound within this game is just drop dead EXCELLENT.  The sounds of gun shots make the feeling of shooting within the game feel meaningful.  the hunting rawrs the robots make when they spot you from a point of view. With so much good to be said about the game. it does come into some faults. One of the coop maps are bit bugged right now. its a bug that disconnects you from the coop map before you even play it. This game requires  a bit of heavy specs to play on if you want to fully take in the experience more smoothly. Overall, for a steam early access game its quite impressive to see how much content has been added and how much more will be added into the future. TLDR: 8.8 out ten.  its a great game but it is a bit of buggy and demands more Mid- high range  PCs to run.

content:
ry 9, 2016
Early Access Review
								Feb 8, 2016I tried this game, really loved the environment.However, as it is PVP bent, it lost at least 50%, if not more, of its potential  market and audience. Sad really that the Developer, and many players, think MMO technology require forced PVP, as though the erroneous assumption of saving money is more important than having money to save...Without buyers of the game, meaning: people who love something about the game so much they'd pay for it and Developers showing respect for that by not forcing them into activities they didn't buy the game for, there is no money to be saved. That is the epicfail of Zeropoint by making the game so PVP based PVE players only see themselves as griefed after paying money. If not for a free weekend one time I probably would have bought this game and been even more ticked off about the situation, of course the Developer probably sees that as a "winning tactic" to get more money, the money their object not developing the game nor having a quality product in the gaming industry over the long-term.In most circles if you buy something and then it changes or is changed away from what it posed itself to be, that's called fraud, better known as "bait and switch," and when the Developer hides behind the Early Access legal fiction AFTER taking our money, and uses this to not develop the game according to the market that has shown interest by paying money, if without intention that's incompetence and they don't deserve to succeed. However, as is usually the case, such as with Starforge, it is with intention and that's called Gross Negligence, which in many cases is tantamount to fraud legally.Point being, if the Developer has abandoned or is not making any effort to make the game appeal to the market, thereby securing the funds by profits from sales, funds they need to develop the game further, then whatever money they want is just stealing, irrespective of whether it's Early Access or not. Buyer beware is the axiom they depend on, which, if the company is actually trying to reach and grow their market is a reasonable idea, however, when the company exercises reckless abandon and utter failure to listen to those who've played the game, fails to pay attention to the cries for the game to be more appealing, and, fails to pay attention to how many walk away because the Developer thinks they can hide behind Early Access and ignore the players, then the entire idea of Early Access fails, and is merely a ruse to steal being taken advantage of by Con-Artists. Buyer beware is not an excuse to defraud peolpe of their money.

content:
2016
Early Access Review
								EDIT: I did a bit of research after writing this and found that the game was actually announced *11* (ELEVEN) years ago.  That's right, this game has been around for over a decade and there still is nothing to show for it.  The most recent update as of May 21st 2016, rather than adding anything meaningful, added a new Main Menu UI and weapon skins, and the option to vote on what map you would like to play when your current round is over.  Two months for weapon skins and a new main menu.  Sorry folks but I don't think that asking for something other than that is very unreasonable at this point.  Please don't drop money on this until the devs have some actual, functionable content ready.I read a preview for the game I want to say around 6-7 years ago in the back of a magazine at the library.  It detailed what the developers wanted to do and how they wanted to do it.  Fast forward 6-7 years and so far we have a slightly above average multiplayer TDM/Domination game put together in Unity.  It's above average because they've obviously spent quite a bit of time and money putting the game together, there are some neat ideas in regard to how guns handle and how you move.  The sound design in particular is very well done, especially noting the differences when you play with your helmet on or off.  I purchased the Spearhead Edition for $45 on their website back in 2010 when I was back in college, back when the game was only playable in your browser and was only a few sets of target practice modes.  If the game had been released shortly after, even 2-3 years later, then it would have been fine.  However, that is simply not the case for Interstellar Marines.The bad parts are, like I mentioned earlier, that this game has been in development hell for what will be coming up on a decade now.  There has been numerous issues, engine changes, failed crowdfunding attempts, "accidental" key giveaways that gave people who purchased the game all of the special legacy upgrades that people who paid $40+ five years ago originally had (Spearhead Edition benefits).  They say the concept is to have an "indie-AAA" where the production values are AAA while being "published by the community."  This is absolutely fine, and it's worked for many other developers and games.  This title, however, has been in development for *years* and the only progress that has been made is adding a relatively uninteresting multiplayer component (You would be *very* lucky to find more than a dozen or so people playing, even on their "Hell Weeks") and a few uninspired singleplayer missions that revolve around you shooting robots, collecting a handful of keycards, and racing to the endpoint.  This would be fine, but the amount of content, and how ultimately boring it turns out to be, is just not worth your time.  The environments are nothing more than large empty hallways and open rooms, with a handful of fences and doors.  Nothing stands out, nothing is memorable.  The robot AI consists of them walking in a straight line and trying to hit you, but they're slow, which means you can easily kill them before they get close.  About 4 years ago they released a standalone "museum" type level that showcased a variety of enemies and environments, none of which have been seen anywhere else in any other part of the game.  The community essentially being dead is the big kicker at this point.  Whoever is left defending the title at this point seem to have a fixation on making sure that there is nothing negative ever said about it.  If you check Youtube, Steam communities, etc, you'll see quite a few people going on about "FOR THE LOVE OF THE GAME", which is a phrase the developers came up with in regards to them developing a very generic coop military space shooter.  ZPS has done a phenomenal job of doing the bare minimum of development and making it out to be part of a massive game changing update.  I used to receive weekly emails that amounted to them saying:"UPDATE: Gun model revisions.UPDATE: Tweaked pistol soundsUPDATE: Added laser sigh, have fun ;)"It's kind of odd to say the least, the devs have been somewhat forthcoming and open about the development process, and they do stay in contact with what little people still have faith in them.  But beyond all that as I mentioned before you aren't going to find a lot of people playing the multiplayer, even during peak hours it's practically impossible to find a full match, don't even get started on trying to find one with decent ping.  All else I can really say is: It's your money, it's $10, the game has been in development hell for years and I cannot in good consciousness recommend that you spend your money on this.  At this point, it's not worth the $40, and it's barely worth $10.  If ZPS can somehow pull something major off then props to them, but the game is just vaporware.  I doubt I'll be able to get my money back since I purchased the game 7 years ago and I doubt they still have records that I bought the game in the first place.

								After some time playing the game and testing all its current features, Interstellar Marines is a game I cannot recommend at its current state. Its a very clunky, floaty, heavy work in progress. The game doesn't run that great, even with my 780ti. Runs at 60 sometimes, but drops to 30 at random locations for no reason.The sound design is pretty great for the most part but there appears to have a lot of gitches. Such as heavy breathing loop, audio cuts, and reverb in areas/senerios where it shouldn't be. EDIT* Sound problems are still as persistent as ever, seems that extended play will lead to that looping heavy breathing gltich. It also lacks content and reply value. There are plenty of maps to play in, but lack of good enough AI and or gunplay to keep it exciting.AI spot you across the map in dark sections of the map no problem and headshot you. AI run into walls, get caught on each other, glitch through stars. This game at its current state is not worth the buy. It carries nothing worth while or different from any modern first person shooter.Your better off playing Blacklight: Retribution, its essentially the same game just with far more content and its free 2 play (thought pay 2 win.)

content:
2015
Early Access Review
								Guns:currently there are 2 guns to use: SMG and AR. the SMG has a lager magazine and is good for small-medium combat, while the AR is good for medium-long range. the combat and maps vary through the game, forcing players to use both weapons to get the most out of the game. Maps and Game modes: In multiplayer there is 4 game modes: deathmatch, team deathmatch, deadlock (deathmatch with capture points), and domination (one big capture point on the map). and there are 8 maps that work with all of these. the map types vary in size and location, and each game mode is fun in its own regard. there is 6 different co-op maps and a range of difficulties which drastically change the co-op gameplay. Player base:The game has a very small player base when compared to other gaming communities, this is both good and bad. there are less trolls in IM and active servers with experienced players can be fun, meanwhile alot of the time there might only be one active server. usually EU and US east are more active then the AU servers, leading to people always having a ping advantage, but there is server rollback to try and make this more fair, but it is always better on a closer server, like any game. Overall:interstellar marines is a fun, but sometimes seems repetitive (mainly co-op), it has enough content to back up the $20 price tag, and has alot of potential for a game that is still pre-alpha.

content:
er 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								As of now, this is a very simple game, but it's really fun. TL;DR at the bottom.Players have only two guns for different ranges of engagement (I find this is very balanced and works well, but they'll probably add more guns in the future). You have infinite ammo reserves, and your weapons have toggleable flashlights, quick attach suppressors, and laser aiming modules. Weapons are reasonably accurate regardless of aiming down sights.I played Survival mode, and I was really pleased with the emergent gameplay.In Survival, you and your co-op partners are put into a large urban/indoor area with objectives strewn around it. You just have to reach each objective to win. Each objective you reach will change the lighting and/or weather of the area, reducing or increasing visibility indoors or outdoors. Objectives can be reached in any order. Killed players can be revived immediately with the press of a button by a teammate. The main component of the gameplay is a steady flow of hostile combat training robots into the area. There are two kinds of robots: melee robots that sprint (really fast), and robots that use guns. Both types can kill you in 1-2 hits. You will usually die before you can react, so you have to listen for them and make sure you see them first. Robots will immediately see and shoot at anyone standing or emitting a source of light, such as a flashlight or light source in the environment. Good players will shoot out lights and use their flashlight sparingly in this mode. The gamemode encourages very tactical movement. Good players will practice sticking together, covering multiple angles, avoiding shooting at the same enemy, timing reloads properly, and entering new areas and rooms sensibly.The graphics are clean and simple, but are likely to be changed as development continues. There is heavy emphasis on atmosphere and lighting that really lends itself to the game, sometimes things get kinda spooky.The sound design of the game is impressive as it is; most of a player's information on how to proceed through an area will be from sounds far, near, muffled through walls, or in the same room.My only technical complaints about the game are the framerate instability and slightly high latency overall; the game is totally playable for me. The game is also a long time in development, it's a crowd-funded game before crowd-funded games were cool. It would be a great shame if the game was not finished. The core gameplay fundamentals are very solid and would probably be called "hard but fair" by a lot of people. It's certainly impressive by modern game's weak standards. The devs cite strong influences for this game: Half-Life, Rainbow Six 3, and System Shock 2. Each one of these influences shows. If the devs stick to their principles, this game can be a nice little pinprick of light in the darkness of recent FPS fare.TL;DR: I recommend trying this game, even in its current state. It's good challenging fun with friends, and despite its simplicity the gameplay does not get old quickly, which is very promising.

content:
28, 2014
Early Access Review
								EDIT: The game is on life support, and that is if I'm being optimistic. It's a real shame to see what this game could have been go down the drain. Below is my review from when it was still alive, and not a vegetable. The game is still good, and you can play singleplayer stuff, but all of the multiplayer is empty... :(This is the best twenty dollars I ever spent. I cannot wait to see what they plan to add to this!THE GOOD:I really enjoy the fast paced gunfights and the slow, nerve-racking calm before them, as you sneak around killer robots in the Neurogen Incident, or just try to get the jump on another player in the versus modes.The multiplayer shines even with only 2 guns, each balanced for their roles perfectly, in my opinion.I have fun with the games singleplayer/CO-OP missions, even if there is only two, because the layout offers a few ways to go about each objective.To add to all this, the game is very immersive, all these small features that just add to the overall game very well such as: Exhaustion affecting aim, No automatic reloads, the ability to remove your visor when the helmet systems die, and even the way breath and rain can appear on your visor.THE BAD:I do have an issue with fps lag however, from all the dynamic lights and reflections and so forth, but its not impacting enough to detract from my enjoyment of the game.I do wish there was more enemies to fight than just a gun robot, and a crazy melee bot.Overall one of the best games I have played.

content:
, 2014
Early Access Review
								In early access this game is severely lacking in features - only 2 different guns, a handful of maps and a control points gamemode that has replaced team deathmatch. Most of the servers are always, depressingly, quite empty. But still, it is a great game. The graphics are smooth, and, one of the best bits, the maps change during games - since the game is set in underground training chambers, the weather and lighting change from broad daylight to pitch darkness to rain and mist. This adds to the atmosphere, and when it's dark, the tension is racked up high, not knowing when you're going to run into an enemy and often too nervous to switch on your flashlight. Also, the gameplay favours tactical and careful movements instead of rushing straight in, which is a nice change from most FPS games out there.At the moment it might not seem like much, but as the developers update the game we are looking forward to new gamemodes, new weapons, and a singleplayer campaign. You should at least pick it up if it goes on sale. It's great fun and is going to become even more fun with future updates.

content:
ry 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is awesome. It has great atmosphere, the gameplay is solid and of course the Robots scare me (a lot!). So buy this game. Also there will eventually be sharks with legs sooo have fun!Edit: Due to a lot of bad reviews I wrote this long 'review thing' defending ZPS and IM, read it or not if you are going to bash IM and write bad reviews do more research on the company first, so many people I have seen just seem to copy/paste what other people wrote and just put the games reviews  even further in the hole when this game DOESN'T deserve it, this game deserves better.(Under is the review thing I was talking about.)4.5 years ago I paid money to a group of individuals saying one simple thing. "We want to make a tactical Sci-Fi shooter", Looking through the ideas and their history gave one implication throughout. THIS IS AN AMBITIOUS PROJECT. I understood this simple fact when I jumped aboard. I knew this would be ambitious, that they were trying to take an old genre with a lot of tropes and copy/pasted games and taking old tactical gameplay present in older games (Rainbow six is one that I can think of right now.) and applying it in a game series with 3 games with 4 player coop that impacted the game and to have each path and role be important, engaging, viable, and realistic. ZPS has been through financial difficulty in the past and they kept working to make their dream a reality, then people come along, the game gets some funds and the developers finally have the platform to release it on steam, start gaining higher levels of income for the game, they finally have a bit more income and start releasing updates. Then they release Hell Week, something that just didn't have the player base to really work, the levels looked awesome the infastructure was promising but due to this simple fact they started getting more and more negative reviews then they reach the "mixed" reviews section of steam. At this point they started losing funding, thus they had less money to make the game better, thus they had less game to make people happy, thus they had less people to give them resources. Then people start yelling and screaming that "ZPS stole our money" and that "they bought coffee with our money". I hate seeing entitled people yell and scream at a company I respect for a multitiude of reasons because they don't have enough game and don't understand and don't care to even look at and do research about the company's history, they just assume that "Im not getting update, game is therefore bad." I do not mean to devalue people's belief's and I believe people have a right to expect a game, but getting mad for supporting a company with barely any resources, while a company like EA takes Star Wars battlefront and monotenizes the crap out of it and gives less and less value with every release (If you like the game great, the gamplay was solid and the maps were well built, I am talking from an hourly content and payment required for "everything in the game") People should be mad at SW Battlefront for not "giving as much content as SW battlefront 2" (People are mad about that but SW battlefront still made so much money it doesn't matter.) And a company who are trying to create value get yelled at for being slow when they have next to no resources and next to no manpower. I support ZPS, I always will, I still believe and it saddens me not many people stand by me on this anymore.

content:
30, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game could be considered great if we were talking about a single-person developer doing this in their free time.  Why? It is a working multiplayer shooter that heavily relies on usage of superior team tactics to win matches - an organised team with voice chat will outmatch a team of "super skilled pro players" with each player doing his own thing. That's the good thing.The bad thing is, that nothing ever happens in term of updates. Every three to six months the developer team wakes up from their beauty sleep, decides what to do for the next hour, puts out massive walls of text praising the amazing new feature (even if it is just a single gun), and then goes back to sleep for the next three months. That would actually be okay if we were talking about a "finished" product, but this isn't a finished product. The way things stand, I can't see any intention of the developer to ever finish this game and implement any of the features promised originally. If you're okay with that and you want a small-scale, team-based, tactical FPS you can of course still go for it. You can of course have a lot of fun with this game as is. But don't expect the grand plan of the developer to happen within the next ten years...

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
2, 2013
Early Access Review
								Game Score: 6/10 - 7/10Interstellar Marines is an excellent game (even though it is in pre-alpha) and looks like it will progress in a direction that is even better. As of this point, the game is drawing closer to a full release and the dedicated developers at Zero Point continue to deliver new content to the game. Visuals and Effects: The visuals on this game (especially for an indie company) are second to none. The particle effects on the rain on your helmet in game is almost realiztic on the highest graphics setting. The scenery (especially in the outside environments) is extremely detailed and well layed out, immersing you in the environment. One shining point of this game is the changing environment, one moment, it could be thundering and pouring. The next, it will be bright and peaceful (with the exception of the sounds of fighting). The lighting is well done and constantly changes. The visual effects of the guns firing is averageSound: Average sound effects, at this point, there are only a few death 'screams' that the Marines will emit upon dying. Gameplay: At this point in development, the game only supports a multiplayer platform. However, the dynamic environment adds so much content to the multiplayer. For example, you could be fighting in a well-let hallway then alarms will start blaring in your ears and the hallway will go dark. Forcing you to choose to use your flashlight or not, which would expose your location. There is a certain level of strategy you must employ when fighting in the ever-changing environment. I would highly reccomend this game to anyone who loves a good and original FPS. The gameplay and visuals (especially the environment) are extremely satisfying and will continue to be improved upon by the developers at Zero Point Software.

content:
, 2014
Early Access Review
								One of my favourite games. I bought the spearhead edition three times (me, my sis and a third copy that's just lying around unclaimed) because I wanted to support the devs.This game is still in a pre-alpha state (i.e. there's still a lot coming) but it's already tons of fun!PROS:-Very dynamic maps (moving platforms, day/night cycles, lights that can be destroyed, doors that open/close) + they are beautiful-Basic implementation of the important stuff: crouch, jump, scope, laser, flashlight, shooting, etc.-The devs are really nice (you can sometimes meet them in-game, and shoot them!)-Updates are regular (every month or so) and of great quality (rather than quantity)-When near death part of the UI will go offline-Very tactical. This is totally not like COD or CS. Winning depends on every member of the team working together rather than a bunch of hyperactive cellar-kids punching their keyboard and mouse to death. Respawn rates are slow, and the only reliable way to get team members to respawn is by capturing points (or killing enemy players if you're the last man standing) this makes games very tense (unless the teams are unbalanced, ↓see below↓)CONS:-Only 2 guns (but more are coming!)-No melee.-No team balancing (has to be done by the players)-No way to kick people (but the players are nice, the only people I've wanted to kick so far were afkers)-No teamchat, voicechat or map/mode voting (it's rumoured these will be added in the next version)-Only multiplayer (so far, co-op and campaign are in the make) EDIT: one co-op scenario has been added a few days ago, although I like it, it's still the most buggy part of the game, I suggest you only play it if you don't mind losing because of invincible bots, random deaths, falling through floors and not knowing what to do. If you do mind, wait until the next update!IMPORTANT POINTS FOR NEW PLAYERS:-Only use your flashlight occasionaly, enemies can see it-Only use your laser when you're gonna use it, enemies can see it-Don't camp, you need to capture points to revive teammates. If you camp (for too long) you're letting your team down.-Keep together. Cover all entrances with your team. Try to flank enemies, force them into corners, etc.-If on your own, watch your back. You're never safe.-Use the SMG for close quarters and the rifle for medium to long shots.-Always. ALWAYS. ALWAYS use cover. There's a lot of it, and it will save your life.-Keep to the dark. When a point/doorway you need is in light, shoot the light. If you don't need to cross a light, don't shoot it. It can help you spot enemies or force them to take another path.-You can't disable alarm lights (red lights) by shooting at them.-Use night/dark to go offensive. As long as you keep to the dark snipers/campers can't spot you.-Don't shoot teammates. When your UI is down (because of damage) try to keep out of combat because it will be very hard to distinguish enemies/friends.It doesn't feel or look like a pre-alpha to me, so I wonder what the game will look like when it's finished.Apparently the next update is going to be a big one. So I'm really looking forward to that, I think it might be co-op. We'll see.

content:
29, 2014
Early Access Review
								Keep in mind one thing before buying this game: This game is in Alpha. Ergo, it's not a finished product.Time of writing this review: 30/03/2014 03:10 AM (+0:00 GMT)I've been meaning to do this review for a while but now I felt I should do it now. Too save you from reading a giant essay on why I love this game. I love everything about it. The community is one of the nicest ones I've encountered, sure, there's teamkillers, but the community notifies one another about a teamkiller if he's ingame with them. The staff team (I've only encountered one and from my experience and the experiences from a few others) are extremely friendly and nice.This game ran on my PC which has a 3.7 GHz Quad Core AMD A10-6700 and 620 GT surprisingly well. Sure, I got 17-20 FPS, but I have to take in account that the game is in alpha, and more optimizations are to be made before the release of the finished product or the release of the beta. The gameplay itself is quite fun, a little slow paced but nothing too slow. You will encounter different dynamic enviroment changes and enviroments. There is rain which can affect your visibility by wettening the visor on your helmet. There's night time which makes you choose between sight and stealth and a few others. The game has a cover system as of Update 10 which is actually better than most game's cover systems in my unprofessional opinion. The gun's recoil is a bit.. much and can be a little frustrating when using the sight to aim down but you really have to fire in burst shots to get the most.This game is quite bug free and glitch free, in my entire month of owning the game, I've only encountered one bug. Which was a wall not being solid and letting the player walk through, could be abused if the wrong people find the bug. (Told the staff member I encountered about it)Tactics isn't really teambased as there's a lack of teamchat unless you're using Steam Chat and that's really it.A little side note: You will be seeing a load of players again and again. It's fun seeing players again and knowing how good they are.

content:
er 27, 2013
Early Access Review
								*** WARNING: This review was written while Interstellar Marines was still in Pre-Alpha status, on November 27th, 2013! ***First things first: If you decide to support Interstellar Marines, make sure you understood what it means that it is an Early Access Title! You are NOT buying a complete game! You are supporting the developers to make their vision come true! Read the store page from top to bottom first.What you get so far when buying the Early Access version:- A single multiplayer mode, "Domination", with multiple servers for several regions available. 5vs5 and 8vs8 is available so far.- "Playgrounds": You can walk around the included multiplayer maps in Singleplayer. There is no goal, you are basically freeroaming the maps so you can learn their layouts without any stress.- Some tech maps for demonstration.- A single weapon with unlimited ammo (30 rounds/clip, with toggleable Flashlight, Laserpointer and Red Dot).- Almost completely bug and lag free game, but not much content.What's NOT available so far:- Singleplayer campaign/missions/shooting galleries.- Coop campaign/missions.- Melee.- Grenades.- Jumping (coming in a few days as I write this!).- Crouching.- A working HUD (only thing you see at the bottom are the remaining bullets in your clip, nothing else)Ok, now that we cleared that and if you're still interested to hear about Interstellar Marines, let me put it this way:Interstellar Marines does not try to be a carbon copy of any large sale franchises which currently exist, like Battlefield or Call of Duty. The developers of Interstellar Marines, Zero Point Software (or ZPS, for short), are some die hard gamers themselves, probably remembering the "good old times" of FPS, which are definitely over today.Playing the multiplayer part of the Early Access version feels very different to those AAA big budget titles released today. One thing which is a very positive thing and a very important one for me personally, is the netcode. I adjusted the network smoothing slider in game all the way to the left, and Interstellar Marines is basically lag free. Something you usually don't find in AAA titles today. If you own Battlefield 4 for example, you know what I'm talking about. Of course Interstellar Marines has the occasional hick up here and there, but that's probably due to the connection of the other players. At least for me, if I experienced lag, it was coming from the same players usually.My own internet connection is pretty slow, but stable. I have a DSL3500 connection with an average ping of 50ms. And like I said, lag free in this game. I usually play on the "All maps (EU)" server.To describe the smoothness of the network code, the last titles I remember to be that smooth were Unreal Tournament (the original one from 1999!), Quake 3 or Counterstrike (not Source, I mean the old one). So if you're an old school gamer like myself and remember at least one of the titles, you know what you're up to. If you have a good aim, you'll hit your enemy. Easy as that.The overall graphics so far are not top of the line of course, but the lighting effects definitely are. The dynamic lighting in the multiplayer maps (remember: all environments are deeply underground in a training facility, with artificial weather, lighting etc.) is creating a tension at night it's mind blowing. I love this! To orientate, you can switch on your flashlight for a short time, but don't use it constantly because it's basically a "shoot here" indicator for your enemies.The performance is great for me, but I got a beefy graphics card. I have all ingame settings maximized, and I get 100+ fps at all times. I'm using a five years old rig with a modern graphics card:Intel Core i7 920 @ 3,6GHz6GB DDR3-1600nVidia GTX770Considering the overall pace of the gameplay, it's quite fast so far. I know ZPS are aiming for a more tactical gameplay like in the very good "Rainbow Six 3: Raven Shield" (never played this game? Go get it!), but it is significantly faster than this right now, but it certainly will change as the game progresses. Playing Interstellar Marines in this current version feels a little similar to Counter Strike Source to me, minus the flashbang, grenade and AWP madness. But don't be fooled, Interstellar Marines has another feature which is, at least in my opinion, outstanding:The sound (engine)!Interstellar Marines allows me to pinpoint the exact location of an enemy if he's giving away his position by making some noise, either by shooting, sprinting or falling off e ledge and landing on the ground. I have a good old 5.1 sound system connected to my dedicated sound card (Creative X-Fi Titanium), and it's been a long time I've been able to tell the exact direction of where a sound came from in a computer game. Doom 3 comes to my mind. So if you're sprinting around too much, people will know exactly where you are and can react accordingly. I love it, love it, love it!One other thing: So far the community does not go into the 100.000s, so don't expect to see a dozen full servers online. We are not there yet, but lately there was usually activity at any time on the EU server.Read a little more about the game and learn where ZPS wants to go with Interstellar Marines, ask questions about it here in the steam forums and decide if this is for you.If you are fed up by annual releases of big franchises with little to no innvations, tons of bugs, lags and bland gameplay, Interstellar Marines could be for you. It will grow and become even better, and so far I'm already having heaps of fun with it in it's very early stage.If you expect explosions every few seconds, choppy controls, a short campaign with little gameplay, boring script events and an absurd storyline for three times the price, there are better titles out there for you.I prefer to support Interstellar Marines though. Without a big publisher, ZPS can concentrate to create the game with a different aim: To make it the game they want, to maximize the fun. Publishers are forcing their developers to maximize only one thing: Revenue, no matter the cost (lack of fun).Support Zero Point Software! Support Interstellar Marines! For the love of the game!

content:
1, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game has the potential to be one of the best, most memorable sci-fi simulators. Unlike most early access games, this is one perhaps truly deserving of attention and in desperate need of funds. IM is one of only a handful of other early access games that I can think of truly in development, and it shows. It has a few place holder items at the moment, that in due time will be replaced. And, unlike almost any other early access title, IM is funded only by your own, and my own patronage - and perhaps the only one not funded by a kickstarter. This game doesn't happen without purchased copies or, if you have an account on the IM website, through small $5 donations. If you don't have an account, but still want to support this game, perhaps without purchasing or lacking enough funds to purchase a copy, go to the Interstellar Marines website, create an account, and make donations here and there. Every little bit helps.

content:
y 18
Early Access Review
								♥♥♥♥.----------------------PROS-----------------------Gunplay. Weapon handling is fantastic. Feels very nice. All the guns feel as they should, though they are few in number. Hit markers point out exactly where you hit on the enemy (more on this in the hud section.) Realistic-ish wounds make them feel as powerful as they should be. Fast paced, react or die mechanics are very enticing.-Hud. The hud is everything you want it to be: good checkpoint markers, fantastic hitmarkers, good scoring module, and fitting colors. It feels very immersive as it gets taken away the second you take off your helmet.-Atmosphere. It's not perfect, but it is certainly a plus. Massive lack of light forces you to rely on your flashlight, surroundings, and mopre importantly, your foes' flashlights. Fantastic scenery immerses you in dark dead space stations and militeristic complexes.-Character design. You are the fist of humanity, crushing aliens, robots, and even other humans that stand in your way. Think of beefed up SWAT in space.-Immersion. Like I said before, this game is very immersive. All your gear is cleverly made to hide the fact that it's a game. The HUD is entirely linked to your futuristic helmet, guns are attached to you via magnetic holsters on your legs and backpack, even the map will be implemented on a wrist-mounted pda. The radio is also pretty darn realistic sounding too.-Promise. The game itself has a bright future, IF it is finished. Mor on this in cons, friends.----------------------CONS-----------------------Development. It's slow. Crawling speed slow. There is only one active dev, though he's incredibly dedicated. Updates take months to come out, and the game itself is struggling to get the needed funding. I pray it's finished.-Content. Yes, it is an early access, but the game is lacking replay value. Two coop missions, some survival, and PVP matches. I really can't wait to see those landsharks in action. Yes sharks with legs, look it up. They cool as flip.-Players. They are nice, but they are few. Very few players make matchmaking a nightmare. Speaking of which...-Servers. There is no hosting a server. Just a warning, as playing with randos will happen. If you're lucky, that is.----------------------TLDR----------------------Fantastic concept and a beautifull future if it gets there. PLEASE just help it get there, friends. Zero Point NEEDS you to help.FOR THE LOVE OF THE GAME.

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
ry 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								Interstellar Marines is a tactical FPS in which two teams of marines are pitted against each other in an underground simulated environment.  Some very unique features of this game include the almost immediate death and the weather mechanics.  This is a game in which the old run n' gun technique will almost always get you killed.  Often the best strategy involves using a suppressor and sneaking around until you can ambush your enemies.Some subjective and personal positive aspects to the game I have noticed are:Losing your HUD once you take a certain amount of damage.  In this game's multiplayer it is nearly impossible to tell friendly soldiers from your enemies without the use of your HUD.  The feature which temporarily removes use of your HUD makes being wounded even more frantic because when you turn to run you need to look twice to make sure the marine behind you is friendly.A feature which closely accompanies the loss of your HUD is the ability to open your helmet.  By pressing "H" you are able to completely disengage your display and open your helmet.  This comes in handy when it is raining because the rain will obstruct your vision by sticking to your visor.Operable doors.Most FPS these days have decided to remove the idea of operable doors in their multiplayer modes.  I beleive that it is a strong suite for this game they have not decided to do that as well.  When opening a door on a map such as Dynacore you can't tell if some one is hiding on the other side.  Doors are also very useful as cover from enemy fire.  It also adds a degree of realism and dynamic gameplay.Weather/Day night system.This game has fully dynamic shadows and a weather system which has been expertly fleshed out.  You have different weather conditions from rain to snow to high winds.  The rain will greatly obstruct your vision while your helmet is down. The snow reduces visibility in general and plays tricks with your mind because of the movement. The winds add slightly more chaos to the area however are likely the least influential of the three.The day and night rotations are incredibly important in any game of Interstellar Marines.  In the day time you have only a very small chance of successfully hiding.  In the dusk and at night you will have a much easier time at remaining concealed.  You will also learn that the use of a flashlight is unadvisable to say the least.  The dynamic changes in weather and time force players to change their strategies whenever the map decides that it got bored.Lastly, the dynamic motions of elements in the maps.Many of the multiplayer maps have different structures of elements within the maps themselves which will periodically move.  This will force players to change their routes and hiding spots as hallways are cut off and buildings rise into the air and sink into the ground.Now for what I dislike about the game in its current state.  Please be advised everything listed below is subject to change.  Alpha = AlphaThe game has very few weapons at the moment.I am personally very happy learning to use two different weapons proficiantly.  But for those of us who want more variation you may have a hard time excepting the lack of variety in your choice of weapons.  On top of this there is only a few small differences in the way the two current weapons handle.  The Rifle has more accuracy over the SMG but it quickly loses that with sustained fire.  The SMG has an additional 10 rounds over the Rifle bringing it to a total of 30.  It also has iron sights with a much lower magnification that allows it to be used in close quarters combat, as opposed to the 4x scope on the Rifle.  However besides these small differences the guns are essentially identical.Movement system.Although perfect in almost all situations, the movement system has its flaws.  The devs have nerfed sprinting and jumping by forcing you to start panting after a certain amount of either running or hopping about.  My concerns with this mechanic in its current state are as follows; Jumping rarely allows you to overcome an obstacle the first try.  After your second or third attempt you begin panting for as long as 20 seconds afterwards.  In multiplayer it can also get tiresome when you are trying to catch up with your team on the map Evacuation and you start to pant, then you encounter and enemy and your crosshair is bouncing all over the screen.Early Access.The game is currently in development.  Listen to me when I say that this game is in EARLY ACCESS.  That means when you buy it you are admitting that this is the product you want in its CURRENT STATE.  Although I think this game deserves all the support it needs to have a successful launch, you must understand that there is no guarantee it will ever be released, and there is no guarentee there will ever be another update.  If you decide to spend your money on this game, I would say its worth every cent.  But at the same time you must make certain you want this game and not the Interstellar Marines that you are thinking about 5 years down the line.Please remember this is a preliminary review of an early access game which is subject to change.  Before perchasing you should look at other reviews and perhaps some video coverage of it online.Thank you,AviatorFox

content:
1, 2015
Early Access Review
								As of this writing, on the startup screen this game is identified as "early access".   The single player gameplay is kinid of old school with very limited story and repetitive fairly plain levels and graphics. On the upside the game seems to run smoothly and the engine is ver responsive and seems well suited to a twitch and shoot. I should mention that I generally don't do multiplayer, or co-op, so can't comment on those modes.  This review is only about the single player mode.  Something that is kind of surprising is that so far in the first two levels, the only enemies are these dumb robots that seem like they are modeled after the "droid" soldiers in Star Wars.  The have a similar metalic voice and the AI is kind of predictable, and a little clutzy and, well, dumb-- just like in Star Wars.  From the title, "Interstallar Marines" I was expecting some aliens or maybe a race of militant humanoids like in Kill Zone.  But, no joy-- all lyou get are these dumb robots.As dissppointing as the robots are, a larger weakness is that there currently seems to be no way to save progress.  What this means is that if you are killed on a level you have  to start over from the beginning.  This is especially painful when almost at the end of a level.  After playing the first level  for about a half hour, and almost "exfiltrating" the compound, I was killed at the last moment (by a dumb robot who didn't die even after I emptied a full clip in hsi stupid face).  The thought of having to start from the beginning was too unpleasant to contemplate, so I quit and played a different game --one with a way to save progress.So far this game has single player potential,  and I like to support Indie developers.  If you wnat to support development then spend a couple of bucks on this early access, but don't expect too much from the single player mode at this  point-- my guess is that the single player mode is more of an after thought with little focus or effort from the developers.  Hopefully there will be an improved single player update soon.

number of helpful: 8 of 14 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
er 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								Reviewed after update 23Gameplay: 300+ hoursCool game mechanics:-Realistic gun recoil -Exhausted?  You will find it harder to aim, your heavy breathing will make it harder to hear also.-Hearing is just as important as seeing.-Minimal hud but still full of tons of information, however it deactivates when your suit is damaged.-That light giving away your position in the dark?  Try shooting it out-React to conditions and accept consequences dynamically.  Silent enviroment? Players/bots will hear you running.  Dark Enviroment?  Players/bots will see your flashlight.  Solo/Coop:-Solid AI, very well done.  Have fun tricking robots into looking behind boxes that they thought you ran behind.  Have fun getting mad when they see your muzzle flash/flashlight from across the map (just like you can).  They have similar restrictions as the player including health.  A fun challange to play on realistic.  -Good assistance and teamwork mechanics.  Its easy to feel hindered when you have a bad team, in fact it is usually easier to play alone than with a bad team.  However with a good team you can cut through maps like melted butter.  Things like needing a teammate to watch your back or cover you while you reload actually can be quite benificial.-Level design and attention to detail.  Some of the best installation designs I've seen in a game.  Can be a bit overwhelming at first, just like if you walked into a real military research base or commercial space station.-Only a few weapons but they are well done and feel right.  Feels like a soldier getting a standard loadout.Multiplayer:-A dynamic training enviroment where the enviroment can wildly change from brightly lit to hurricane condtions to pitch black.  Very fun and totally changes the way the match is playing.-Want to run and gun?  That is okay but deal with the exhaustion and inability to aim well.  Want to run around with a laser sight (which acts as a crosshair) then be ready to give away your position.  There is no wrong answer to tactics, just results.tl;dr:This game is fun and enjoyable.  Get to watch a single person take out a whole team using stealth in the dark.  Watch people complain that stealth has no purpose. 11/10 would play again.

content:
3, 2016
Early Access Review
								Think Aliens, crossed with Arma.Kind of what that other AAA aliens and marines based game could have/should have been if it wasn't a load of old ♥♥♥♥. Now I know it's been in development for a long time, but it has been developing - albiet not as fast as some users according to several reviews on here.. But that has to be the only negative for the game though. The gun play is excellent, even with only a few weapons in the game, they're so well done and work so well in their respective uses I personally don't miss having a variety of rifles or SMGs or rocket launchers.. The lore of the game so far is that you're in a training facility under the Nevada desert, so there doesn't yet need to be many kinds of rifle or whatever else. The use of either Pistol, AR or SMG is fine enough for the current lore of the game.And that HUD! I've yet to see a better implemented HUD; properly a part of your helmet's visor - with the option of raising the visor on your helmet to maybe see better in the rain or fog, at the cost of losing your HUD altogether. Such immersion, I haven't seen this done so well before. PVP is very well done, akin to DayZ/Arma; tactics and positioning are everything.Teamplay and moving from position to position, hugging the walls, keeping in the shadows, makes the difference between winning or losing. Sprinting about trying to run and gun will only get you so far, that is not very far at all! The multiplayer maps are all excellent, from cramped storage facilities with ledges and corridors (reminds me of laser quest as a child) to open spaced maps with water, fog, thick undergrowth and hiding places galore.. The simulated sunny/rainy/day/sunset/night cycling of the 'training environment' that the matches are held in constantly adds new elements to your fight. Co-op matches are also good, the AI can pose a very real threat, although still no land sharks or aliens as yet. The missions are good - clearing a map of hostiles, infiltrating a facility, sneaking round and picking off sentries while vastly outnumbered and so on. But I have to be honest I mostly play for the PVP. As things develop and the game gets further along its trajectory  and original aim of co-op teamplay I can't wait to get a team together to see what bug infested space hulks we could explore ;)So I do highly recommend; no it might not fill several hundreds of hours just yet (though some have got thousands of hours on their profiles) all the same for the small price tag and the huge potential, it has to be a win. It's less than the price of a couple of pints these days. How can you possibly go wrong. (I've been waiting two years for a different dev team (with millions € behind them) to add zombies back in to their zombie survival game, surely this small indie team of devs are worth waiting on to get us our aliens and land sharks sorted ;) )Stay frosty people.

content:
ry 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is the reason why I don't like the Idea of early access.  The whole point of Early access is so that you can support the game you want while its in development.  When in development the goal is usually to make a rough wireframe of the game.  As everyone knows, you can't edit and refine what doesn't exist. However, this team doesn't know this.  They have forgotten what their goals were for this game.  They have been making small updates forside content which is (usually) suppose to be second to the main content.  They seem to want to appease players with small updates so that they can forever have a stream of money, with no effort involved.  This game will most likely not ever be completed, and having bought the game I am severely dissappointed in them.  What they have made so far has nothing to do with anything they had promised me when I purchased.  Years will pass by and almost no progress will be made.  It will most likely be dropped into the abyss called canceled project, if they haven't quit already.In a few years this game will be forgotten, and nobody will miss it.

ber 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								IMPORTANT NOTE: This is only for the Early Access content as of August 2014. My rating is subject to change once more is added.The Review: ISM is very lite on content, to me. It has a couple multiplayer competitive maps, and a early demo for Co-op mode where you and a friend kill robots while trying to reach the roof. 2 guns, no grenades or customization or any other weapons, not even melee. The 2 guns are both Assault Rifles with emphasis on different engagement ranges. I see the potential for an amazing game, but right now it's just too simple. The lighting adds a good layer to the game, as well as the decision to use a laser and give away your position in return for better hip aiming. It seems you can take off your helmet but this currently seems to have no effect other than removing the hud; I assume this will result in your suit powering down (no lights) eventually, but it's not the case currently. In summary: If you are you are interested in their concept, get this on sale maybe. I got it in a Humble Bundle and don't regret it. But if you want a good game to sink hours into, I don't see it happening here, yet. Keep an eye on ISM though, I do expect it to become awesome eventually.

								Sharks. With. Legs.(Early Access Review 26/07/2015 Update 20 Unity 5)Interstellar Marines is rich in story, development story firstly.This is a game that was originally created in the Unreal Engine at the wrong side of the economic crash.The outcome? A bankrupt studio and no way of affording the price of the then current Unreal pricing model.So what did they do?Give up?Of course not!They just shrugged it off and started in Unity Engine.20 updates later and here we are at the Unity 5 update.So what is this game all about in its current state?What will it be like when it is finished?Will it even be finished?Why does everyone keep talking about sharks?Is the IM community really that awesome?Currently the game is all about the multiplayer, the single player and the co-op and most recently it is all about hellweek.Multiplayer is fun, difficult, tense and frantic.Single player is unnerving, tense and atmospheric.Co-op is fulfilling and to be honest, a worthy challenge.Hellweek is ambitious, sometimes cruel and unique.When finished IM will probably be the best science fiction fps and I would go as far as saying it will probably be the bar that all other sci-fi games are judged on for single player story going forward.Not even bankruptcy can put IM down so it seems safe to say that this game will get finished.Sharks are scary enough at the best times but these abominations have legs. Have you even considered how scary it would be to get chased down in first person by a great white sprinting at you?Some say that the IM community is the best community by far, all I know is that a game is only as good as its community when it comes to games with multiplayer.I've been vague on this review, but just wanted to add more and keep building on it so it's the start.

content:
ber 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								The game certainly has potential, but the same can be said about a lot of titles that have not delivered what was promised.  While graphically pleasing, the game currently lacks what I consider to be any decent gameplay.  Multiplayer death matches are pretty much all you have to look forward to if you buy this game which is *not* worth the money in my opinion.  With these things in mind I will point out the pros and cons of this game as best as I see them. Pros:(The graphics are more than I expected and makes the game look quite believeable.(Weapon performance is surprsingly good, with the sounds and recoil reminding me of actual rifles I have fired.(The heads up display mixed with the toggle modes on the helmet makes me feel like my head is actually in the helmet, which reminds me somewhat of the metro series.  This is a great immersion modifier.(The dynamic weather system the have in the arena is very well done and they demonstrate that they can develope immersive environments within their game.Cons:(While the devs have multiple "gamemodes", all of them occur within an enclosed arena which, for me, gets dull really fast.  Again, the lack of gameplay variety just ruins this for me.(Next to no visible progress on this game.  I understand the time it takes to develope such things but their updates  are both irregular and sparse.  I see no indication that this game is going anywhere fast.(Lack of player customization leaves me feeling like a stormtrooper with no identity.  This breaks the immersion greatly in my mind.Overall I'd say that this game has the barebones framework that can be the foundation of something awesome, but sadly I don't believe it will be.  As I said, I see no noteworthy progress on the game and with that fact alone, I don't reccomend buying this game.

content:
ry 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've been following this game, for a few years; basically I seen mutant land sharks, and well I am still left waiting for it. Lets be honest this game is early access but its good, the basics are there, and the shooting omg, I havent played a game that I feel like Im actually hitting where I aim. Perhaps many will say its unrealistic as there doest seem to have any variation of flight, but damn it feels good to know you as the player are on point.  Where is the game now? Well, its playable with a some bugs that are easily repeatable but nothing that breaks the game. There are 7 maps, and really it doesnt seem like much. And once you clear them all with you group of friends its hard to go back to them. And you will need friends, this game can be hard and failing is a part of it, but with a full group of friends there are alot of tactics to try in all the maps  in all the modes. It just feels like there isnt enough game yet, esp with updates so far between eachother. The online server chooser needs to be fleshed out a bit, currently a slight pain to get a game going, but not hard either, just missing some nicities. So for me and my group, there isnt enough yet for us to buy into I.M.'s Early Access yet. BUT if an update adds the sharks and give me some LAN play, I'm all in. It just need a bit more.

content:
ry 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								From what I played, this game is goregeous. It doesn't really rely on online multiplayer team vs. team combat like most FPS nowadays. You can play singleplayer missions, co-op with a few friends, and if you really want to, you can play multiplayer. Visually, it's stunning. The effects on the visor are new to sci-fi shooters and really haven't seen that done before. I didn't get my chance to try out multiplayer against other players quite yet, and don't think I'll get the chance for a while. Although this game is fantastic, and is different from the many shooters that it's in the market against, it lacks one thing that might make this better for us, not so rich people that can't afford to buy a gaming pc. A graphics tab. It does have the v-sync, etc. stuff, but I maybe want to lower some of the quality to medium instead of always being on high. For laptop users, like myself, this is a big issue that we have to deal with. I'm not saying my laptop is terrible graphically or anything, but a graphics tab, visual quality slider could be useful to many players. Other than that, this game is fantasic and hell yeah I recommend it to a friend!
